title: Electron/Atom processes displayed wrong in process list

milestone.title: Glances 3.0
milestone.description: Glances 3.0 roadmap with all issues breaking the API.

body:
#### Description

Process list shows a shortened/partial string for electron apps like Discord, and misidentifies the process name.

Actual ps output:
```
towo      9912  1.6  2.1 2345544 340136 tty2   Sl+  Nov23  18:17 /opt/discord/Discord --type=renderer --no-sandbox --primordial-pipe-token=<TOKEN REMOVED> --lang=en-GB --app-path=/opt/discord/resources/app.asar --node-integration=true --background-color=#282b30 --enable-blink-features=EnumerateDevices,AudioOutputDevices --hidden-page --enable-pinch --num-raster-threads=2 --enable-main-frame-before-activation --content-image-texture-target=0,0,3553;0,1,3553;0,2,3553;0,3,3553;0,4,3553;0,5,3553;0,6,3553;0,7,3553;0,8,3553;0,9,3553;0,10,3553;0,11,3553;0,12,3553;0,13,3553;0,14,3553;0,15,3553;1,0,3553;1,1,3553;1,2,3553;1,3,3553;1,4,3553;1,5,3553;1,6,3553;1,7,3553;1,8,3553;1,9,3553;1,10,3553;1,11,3553;1,12,3553;1,13,3553;1,14,3553;1,15,3553;2,0,3553;2,1,3553;2,2,3553;2,3,3553;2,4,3553;2,5,3553;2,6,3553;2,7,3553;2,8,3553;2,9,3553;2,10,3553;2,11,3553;2,12,3553;2,13,3553;2,14,3553;2,15,3553;3,0,3553;3,1,3553;3,2,3553;3,3,3553;3,4,3553;3,5,3553;3,6,3553;3,7,3553;3,8,3553;3,9,3553;3,10,3553;3,11,3553;3,12,3553;3,13,3553;3,14,3553;3,15,3553 --disable-accelerated-video-decode --service-request-channel-token=<TOKEN REMOVED> --renderer-client-id=6 --v8-natives-passed-by-fd --v8-snapshot-passed-by-fd
```

What `glances` shows:
```
app.asar --node-integration=true --background-color=#282b30 --enable-blink-features=EnumerateDevices,AudioOutputDevices --hidden-page [...]
```

(The rest of the line is there, just not easily copypastable due to terminal size limits)

Similar things happen with spotify:
```
/opt/spotify/spotify --type=gpu-process --no-sandbox --lang=en-US --log-file=/opt/spotify/debug.log --log-severity=disable --product-version=Spotify/1.0.64.407 --supports-dual-gpus=false --gpu-driver-bug-workarounds=1,9,27,70,84 --disable-gl-extensions=GL_KHR_blend_equation_advanced GL_KHR_blend_equation_advanced_coherent --disable-accelerated-video-decode --gpu-vendor-id=0x8086 --gpu-device-id=0x1616 --gpu-driver-vendor --gpu-driver-version --gpu-driver-date --lang=en-US --log-file=/opt/spotify/debug.log --log-severity=disable --product-version=Spotify/1.0.64.407 --service-request-channel-token=<TOKEN REMOVED>
```

vs. glances command column:
```
1.0.64.407 --service-request-channel-token=<TOKEN REMOVED>
```

The removed tokens are of course hex strings. Additionally, the whole command is highlighted green, like a process name.

Since the cut-off seems to be  `--app-path=/opt/discord/resources/` and `--production-version=Spotify/` respectively, I'm guessing some sort of regular expression is being overzealous.

#### Versions
```
% glances -V
Glances v2.11.1 with psutil v5.4.1
% lsb-release -a
LSB Version:    1.4
Distributor ID: Arch
Description:    Arch Linux
Release:        rolling
Codename:       n/a
```

title: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\U0001f4a9' in position 4: ordinal not in range(128)

milestone.title: Glances 3.0
milestone.description: Glances 3.0 roadmap with all issues breaking the API.

body:
With the wifi module enabled, I get an uncaught exception due to a neighbor's weird wifi name.     

The exact exception I get is:
`UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\U0001f4a9' in position 4: ordinal not in range(128)`     

The issue is caused from the following line of code (glances_wifi.py:200)
`msg = '{:{width}}'.format(hotspotname, width=ifname_max_width)`    

The cause being that the default encoding for strings when using format is 'ascii'. This won't be able to handle all characters that are allowed in a ssid (i.e. my neighbors wifi which is: Grey💩On) . 

The code could handle this by replacing unknown characters with '?' or by trying to use UTF-8 instead.

title: Permission denied: '/etc/mtab' with the Glances' Snap version

milestone.title: Glances 3.0
milestone.description: Glances 3.0 roadmap with all issues breaking the API.

body:
#### Description

Install Glances using Snap on Ubuntu.

Snap configuration file: https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/develop/snap/snapcraft.yaml

body:
#### Description

Glances report wrong total disk size on my large 20TB disk on macOS 10.13 using APFS format. The total usage size is correct and disk size is in green color. 
```
_ore Data  33.7G  2.19T
```
When switching to showing available size, the disk size is also in green color.
```
_ore Data  2.16T  2.19T

There is no error on computing the usage size and usage percentage. It seems it is just a bug for formatting the total disk size.

/dev/disk5s1     19T   34G   19T   1% /Volumes/Core Data
```

title: Client and Quiet mode don't work together
body:
Before filling this issue, please read the manual (https://glances.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) and search if the bug do not already exists in the database (https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/issues).

title: `UnicodeDecodeError` on mountpoints with non-breaking spaces
body:
#### Description

While an external HDD of mine, with a NTFS partition named `HDD TOURO LGD` (with non-breaking spaces, of course non-ASCII) is connected to my PC (running Fedora 25 on x86_64) and its filesystem automatically mounted on `/run/media/lgd/HDD TOURO LGD`, when I run `glances`, I only see the traceback written lower (`UnicodeDecodeError…`), and the software exits with the status `1`.

###### Steps to reproduce

- Create a NTFS partition named with non-breaking spaces on an external hard drive.
- Connect the HDD to a Fedora 25-running PC, and let the OS mount the filesystem automatically to `/run/media/username/<name with non-breakin spaces`
- Run `glances`

#### Versions

* Glances (glances -V): 2.10
* PSutil (glances -V): 5.2.2
* Operating System (lsb_release -a): Fedora release 25 (Twenty Five)

title: Python encoding in python2 and python3
body:
In python2, binary type is native string type, so function b and nativestr should be the same. In python3, unicode is native string and binary is encoded unicode type. Now the question comes, why do we encode unicode string in python3 by encode('latin-1') instead using utf-8?

Note: I fixed the bug for ZeroMQ by modifying the compat file, still needs further test system wide to make sure the type checking and translating is totally correct.

#### Description

The original code is causing "Frame does not support the buffer interface" error in ZeroMQ @ https://github.com/zeromq/pyzmq/blob/master/zmq/sugar/socket.py line 373 in socket.recv_multipart. I looked up the code and find out the function b() in glances.compat is actually returning the unicode object. So it's basically a bug of unicode does not support buffer interface, which can be solved by encode str before sending.

#### Resume

* Bug fix: yes
* New feature: no
* Fixed tickets: comma-separated list of tickets fixed by the PR, if any

title: When exporting, uptime values loop after 1 day
body:
#### Description

When exporting to StatsD/Graphite, the Uptime values being returned by Glances do not reflect the ones in the UI.  Instead they reset to 0 every 24 hours.

I believe this is caused by the use of the seconds property on the timedelta.  In glances_uptime.py, in the  "get_export" function self.uptime.seconds is returned. For timedelta this the seconds part of the difference, but I believe the totalseconds() method should be used to return the whole difference in seconds. 

From the timedelta help():
 **|  total_seconds(...)
 |      Total seconds in the duration.**
 |  
 |  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 |  Data descriptors defined here:
 |  
 |  days
 |      Number of days.
 |  
 |  microseconds
 |      Number of microseconds (>= 0 and less than 1 second).
 |  
 **|  seconds
 |      Number of seconds (>= 0 and less than 1 day).**

#### Versions

* Glances (glances -V): 2.9.1
* PSutil (glances -V): 5.2.1
* Operating System (lsb_release -a):

#### Logs
Since the data is being exported without exceptions, instead of the glances log, here is an example of one of the stats rolling over.  You can see it hit 85785 seconds (23 hours 49 minutes), and then the next interval is 285

title: Some FS and LAN metrics fail to export correctly to StatsD
body:
#### Description
When running with --export-statsd; some metrics are not translating over correctly and throw exceptions in StatsD.

- FS metrics are sent with special characters in the stats name (On windows, so filesystem = C:\\, which then fails in StatsD) 
-- 27 Mar 11:01:29 - DEBUG: Bad line: **\\.free** in msg "glances.fs.**C:\\**.free:3366996787
- LAN Metrics send boolean True/False instead of numeric, and get a similar error.
--27 Mar 11:01:29 - DEBUG: Bad line: **False**,g in msg "glances.network.Local Area Connection* 11.is_up:False|g"
--27 Mar 11:01:29 - DEBUG: Bad line: **False**,g in msg "glances.network.isatap.mtg.home.ads.is_up:False|g"
--27 Mar 11:01:29 - DEBUG: Bad line: **True**,g in msg "glances.network.Local Area Connection.is_up:True|g"
--27 Mar 11:01:29 - DEBUG: Bad line: **True**,g in msg "glances.network.Loopback Pseudo-Interface 1.is_up:True|g"

A naive solution might be to filter out non-alphanum in the stat_name:
`stat_name = filter(lambda x: str.isalnum(x) or x == '.',stat_name)`
I don't know if that would play nice across all platforms though, maybe it would make more sense to swap \ and / to _.  
Then convert the stat_value to int when sending the gauge, so it's within the try/catch just in case this fails.  The bools translate nicely over to 0/1.  I don't think you'd ever want a non-int metric value here
`try:`
`    self.client.gauge(stat_name, int(stat_value))`
`except Exception as e:`
`    logger.error("Can not export stats to Statsd (%s)" % e)`


#### Versions

* Glances (glances -V): v2.8.8
* PSutil (glances -V): v5.2.1
* Operating System (lsb_release -a): Windows 7 

#### Logs
Below is the StatsD Logfile, does not appear in Glances log (which makes sense - metrics are delivered)

> 27 Mar 11:27:34 - DEBUG: Bad line: False,g in msg "glances.network.isatap.mtg.home.ads.is_up:False|g"
> 27 Mar 11:27:34 - DEBUG: Bad line: True,g in msg "glances.network.Local Area Connection.is_up:True|g"
> 27 Mar 11:27:34 - DEBUG: Bad line: True,g in msg "glances.network.Loopback Pseudo-Interface 1.is_up:True|g"
> 27 Mar 11:27:34 - DEBUG: Bad line: \.free in msg "glances.fs.C:\.free:33671733248|g"
> 27 Mar 11:27:34 - DEBUG: Bad line: \.size in msg "glances.fs.C:\.size:106848841728|g"
> 27 Mar 11:27:34 - DEBUG: Bad line: \.percent in msg "glances.fs.C:\.percent:68.5|g"
> 27 Mar 11:27:34 - DEBUG: Bad line: \.used in msg "glances.fs.C:\.used:73177108480|g"

title: On Windows --export-statsd  terminates immediately and does not export.
body:
#### Description
- When executing --export-statsd on Windows; glances terminates immediately and does not export stats
- Based on the below; assuming this is an issue with the --export in general, as standalone mode cannot be started on Windows
- It appears this is a regression from 2.8.6 related to the fix of "Global name standalone not defined (#1030)" which reverted the fix from #1038 in __init__ to 
   if core.is_standalone()and not WINDOWS: from    if core.is_standalone():
- Commenting out "and not WINDOWS" causes the export to function as expected.

#### Versions

* PSutil (glances -V): v5.2.0

title: Crashs after long time running the glances --browser (recursion exceeded)
body:
Hello,

Sorry for this unusual bug report.

Currently i'm using the Glances v2.8.8

After some times (hours) keeping running the "glances --browser" it's always crashing with the message: "maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object" (the complete dump is in the end of this message)

Investigating the problem I found that the method __serve_forever in GlancesClientBrowser class in client_browser.py runs recursively for ever, so after running during some time this recursion finally exceeds the python recursion limit giving the crashes:
```
def __serve_forever(self):
        """Main client loop."""
        # No need to update the server list
        # It's done by the GlancesAutoDiscoverListener class (autodiscover.py)
        # Or define staticaly in the configuration file (module static_list.py)
        # For each server in the list, grab elementary stats (CPU, LOAD, MEM, OS...)

        logger.debug("Iter through the following server list: {}".format(self.get_servers_list()))
        for v in self.get_servers_list():
            thread = threading.Thread(target=self.__update_stats, args=[v])
            thread.start()

        # Update the screen (list or Glances client)
        if self.screen.active_server is None:
            #  Display the Glances browser
            self.screen.update(self.get_servers_list())
        else:
            # Display the active server
            self.__display_server(self.get_servers_list()[self.screen.active_server])

        # Loop
        self.__serve_forever()
```

To fix it I made change my glances client_browser.py removing the recursive loop and using a while instead:
```
 def __serve_forever(self):
        """Main client loop."""
        # No need to update the server list
        # It's done by the GlancesAutoDiscoverListener class (autodiscover.py)
        # Or define staticaly in the configuration file (module static_list.py)
        # For each server in the list, grab elementary stats (CPU, LOAD, MEM, OS...)

        while True:

                logger.debug("Iter through the following server list: {}".format(self.get_servers_list()))
                for v in self.get_servers_list():
                    thread = threading.Thread(target=self.__update_stats, args=[v])
                    thread.start()

                # Update the screen (list or Glances client)
                if self.screen.active_server is None:
                    #  Display the Glances browser
                    self.screen.update(self.get_servers_list())
                else:
                    # Display the active server
                    self.__display_server(self.get_servers_list()[self.screen.active_server])

        # Loop
        #self.__serve_forever()
```

This fixed the problem for me, so now I'm here posting this bug report to help any other that tried to use glances has a multi-server monitor.

title: Fails to start, OSError in sensors_temperatures
body:
#### Description
Glances fails to start (as of a few weeks ago). It might not be directly related to glances, since it used to work, and I think an unrelated Arch Linux upgrade might've broken it.

#### Versions

* Glances (glances -V): v2.8.8
* PSutil (glances -V): v5.2.0
* Operating System (lsb_release -a): Arch Linux (kernel 4.10.3)

#### Logs
```
2017-03-20 11:13:13,138 -- INFO -- Start Glances 2.8.8
2017-03-20 11:13:13,138 -- INFO -- CPython 3.6.0 and PSutil 5.2.0 detected
2017-03-20 11:13:13,140 -- INFO -- Start standalone mode
2017-03-20 11:15:45,817 -- INFO -- Start Glances 2.8.8
2017-03-20 11:15:45,817 -- INFO -- CPython 3.6.0 and PSutil 5.2.0 detected
2017-03-20 11:15:45,819 -- INFO -- Start standalone mode
2017-03-20 11:17:01,483 -- INFO -- Start Glances 2.8.8
2017-03-20 11:17:01,483 -- INFO -- CPython 3.6.0 and PSutil 5.2.0 detected
2017-03-20 11:18:36,997 -- INFO -- Start Glances 2.8.8
2017-03-20 11:18:36,997 -- INFO -- CPython 3.6.0 and PSutil 5.2.0 detected
2017-03-20 11:18:37,000 -- INFO -- Start standalone mode
```
#### Trace
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/glances", line 11, in <module>
    load_entry_point('Glances==2.8.8', 'console_scripts', 'glances')()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glances/__init__.py", line 225, in main
    start_standalone(config=config, args=args)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/glances/__init__.py", line 105, in start_standalone
    standalone = GlancesStandalone(config=config, args=args)

body:
I am exporting glances into infludb, but the following error happens and meanwhile glances crashed:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/threading.py", line 801, in __bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/glances/glances/plugins/glances_ports.py", line 173, in run
    self._port_scan(p)
  File "/glances/glances/plugins/glances_ports.py", line 201, in _port_scan
    if int(port['port']) == 0:
TypeError: string indices must be integers, not str
```

Both of my glances service and influxdb service are managed by docker , here is my docker-compose.yml:

```
version: "2"
services:
  grafana:
    image: grafana/grafana
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
    depends_on:
      - "influxdb"
  glances:
    image: "nicolargo/glances"
    #tty: true
    # stdin_open: true
    environment:
     - "GLANCES_OPT=--export-influxdb -q"
    # entrypoint: /bin/bash
    volumes:
      - "/var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock:ro"
      - "./conf:/glances/conf"
    depends_on:
      - "influxdb"
    pid: "host"
  influxdb:
    image: tutum/influxdb:latest
    environment:
      - "ADMIN_USER=root"
      - "INFLUXDB_INIT_PWD=root"
      - "PRE_CREATE_DB=glances"
    volumes:
      - "./influx:/data"
    ports:
      - "8086:8086"
      - "8083:8083"
    expose:
      - "8090"
      - "8099"
```

I print several logs in glances_ports.py, and I found the code in the method "_port_scan" ,
```
    def _port_scan(self, port):
        """Scan the port structure (dict) and update the status key"""
        logger.error("ports may contains error -{}".format(port))
        if int(port['port']) == 0:
            return self._port_scan_icmp(port)
        else:
            return self._port_scan_tcp(port)
```

title: /proc/interrupts not found when running Glances in an OpenVZ container
body:
First, the Versions!:
Glances v2.7.1 with psutil v2.2.1
LSB Version:    :core-4.1-amd64:core-4.1-noarch
Distributor ID: CentOS
Description:    CentOS Linux release 7.2.1511 (Core) 
Release:    7.2.1511
Codename:   Core
This is an OpenVZ container!

This version of Glances don't run inside a container because it don't have access to /proc/interrupts from inside:

`Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/glances", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('Glances==2.7.1', 'console_scripts', 'glances')()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/__init__.py", line 127, in main
    args=core.get_args())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/standalone.py", line 68, in __init__
    self.stats.update()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/stats.py", line 154, in update
    self._plugins[p].update()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/plugins/glances_plugin.py", line 734, in wrapper
    ret = fct(*args, **kw)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/plugins/glances_irq.py", line 66, in update
    with open('/proc/interrupts') as irq_proc:
IOError: [Errno 2] Arquivo ou diretório não encontrado: '/proc/interrupts'`

The is that glance don't found it and have a fatal error that don't allow it to run, even if I put --disable-irq parameter in command line.

The ideal solution would be to test if the "file" exists and if not, ignore the display of IRQs without major hassles with or without disable-irq parameter.

To workaround the problem I added to "glances/plugins/glances_irq.py" a "import os.path", and changed the line "if not LINUX:" to "if not LINUX or not os.path.isfile('/proc/interrupts'):" but I don't know if this is the ugly solution is the best one (so I won't open a PR).

Sorry for any bad english (is not my native language)

title: zeroconf problem with zeroconf service name
body:
On my server `socket.gethostname()` returns a real FQDN like `server.domain.com`.

Recent version of zeroconf doesn't like a service name with dots.

It triggers an exception when trying `glances -s`.

I had to patch this way:

```
--- a/glances/server.py
+++ b/glances/server.py
@@ -212,7 +212,7 @@

         if not self.args.disable_autodiscover:
             # Note: The Zeroconf service name will be based on the hostname
-            self.autodiscover_client = GlancesAutoDiscoverClient(socket.gethostname(), args)
+            self.autodiscover_client = GlancesAutoDiscoverClient(socket.gethostname().split('.', 1)[0], args)
         else:
             logger.info("Glances autodiscover announce is disabled")
```

title: zeroconf problem with zeroconf_type = "_%s._tcp." % __appname__
body:
Recent versions of the zeroconf python package doesnt like a zeroconf type that ends with '._tcp.'.

It triggers an exception when trying `glances --browser`.

I had to patch this way:

```
--- a/glances/autodiscover.py
+++ b/glances/autodiscover.py
@@ -47,7 +47,7 @@
         sys.exit(1)

 # Global var
-zeroconf_type = "_%s._tcp." % __appname__
+zeroconf_type = "_%s._tcp.local." % __appname__


 class AutoDiscovered(object):
```

title: Improper bytes/unicode in glances_hddtemp.py
body:
Hello,

with python3.4 and hddtemp enabled, i can't get access to the web interface.

Digging in the HTTP traffic shows an API call to api/2/all that fails, with a JSON encoding error (choking on bytes data).

Indeed `glances_hddtemp.py` seems to have an encoding problem with the temperature value.

In `GlancesGrabHDDTemp.__update__`:

`temperature = fields[offset + 3]` means that temperature has 'bytes' type

then `hddtemp_current['value'] = float(temperature) if isinstance(temperature, numbers.Number) else temperature` ==> `if isinstance(temperature, numbers.Number)` is always False ==> `hddtemp_current['value']` has also 'bytes' type

instead, maybe do:

``` python
try:
    hddtemp_current['value'] = float(temperature)
except ValueError:
    hddtemp_current['value'] = nativestr(temperature)
```

Hope it helps :)

title: Network I/O is off in InfluxDB/Grafana
body: #### Description The network I/O in my grafana dashboard does not match what I see when I run glances from the command line. See picture below: As you can see, it's not something straightforward like not using the correct units – glances is currently displaying KBps and Grafana is displaying the graph with bytes/sec units. I considered trying to figure out a multiplier to add to the measurements, but I'm having trouble figuring out an appropriate value. In the example above, I would want to multiply the value Grafana (via InfluxDB) sees by ~1/3. Glances: Rx/s: 15Kbps Tx/s: 49Kbps Grafana: Rx/s: 50Kbps Tx/s: 153Kbps My suggestion of editing the Grafana query to multiply the result by 0.33333 would get close results (~16Kbps and ~51Kbps) in this example, but it doesn't always work out that nicely, and I find that to be a hacky solution. I also don't understand the significance of why Grafana would report the value ~3 times higher than it is. Thank you so much for your help! #### Versions - Glances (glances -V): Glances v2.7_BETA - PSutil (glances -V): v4.1.0 - Operating System (lsb_release -a): Ubuntu 14.04 LTS

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/glances/plugins/glances_docker.py", line 297, in get_docker_memory
    ret['rss'] = all_stats['memory_stats']['stats']['rss']
TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not subscriptable
```

In the brief time glances is displayed, I noticed the docker stats are mostly "?" instead of numeric:

```
docker0       0b     0b    Name                               Status  CPU%    MEM IOR/s IOW/s  Rx/s  Tx/s Command 
eth0          0b     0b    gemstash_server          Up About an hour   0.0      ?     ?     ?     ?     ? gemstash start --no-daemonize
```

I have one container running and `docker stats gemstash_server` appears normal:

```
CONTAINER           CPU %               MEM USAGE / LIMIT     MEM %               NET I/O             BLOCK I/O           PIDS
gemstash_server     0.01%               35.75 MB / 25.23 GB   0.14%               4.994 kB / 648 B    0 B / 0 B           0
```

If I have no containers running, glances will run fine without the docker section.
I did upgrade docker to the newest this morning (v 1.11.0). I don't see anything obvious in the release notes that would have broken stats API: https://github.com/docker/docker/releases
I downgraded docker-engine to 1.10.3 and glances did not error out. Here's the output of docker stats again:

```
CONTAINER           CPU %               MEM USAGE / LIMIT    MEM %               NET I/O             BLOCK I/O
gemstash_server     0.00%               35.7 MB / 25.23 GB   0.14%               4.125 kB / 648 B    0 B / 0 B
```
#### Versions
- Glances (glances -V): Glances v2.6.1 
- PSutil (glances -V): psutil v4.1.0
- Operating System (lsb_release -a): Ubuntu 14.04.4

title: CSV export: Data lines with more columns than expected
body:
#### Description

I was running glances with CSV export on a Windows 2008 Server R2 SP1 64-Bit to collect data for 24 hours. The following command was used for the data collection:

```
glances.exe --export-csv C:\tmp\glances_out.csv -1 -b --diskio-iops -t 1 -q
```

During analysis of the collected data, I found lines where glances is writing too much columns for the snapshot lines. Please find an example snippet below (I've removed the first columns for better readability):

```
diskio_PhysicalDrive1_disk_name,diskio_PhysicalDrive1_key,diskio_PhysicalDrive1_read_bytes,processcount_sleeping,processcount_running,processcount_thread,processcount_total,cpu_user,cpu_system,cpu_total,cpu_idle
PhysicalDrive1,disk_name,212992,0,131,1553,131,1.5,49.2,0.0,49.2
PhysicalDrive1,disk_name,212992,0,132,1555,132,1,3.0,0.0,50.0,100.0
```

![glances_out_csv_in_excel](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/15014728/14506094/70aa62fa-01bc-11e6-8bee-7f4ef75546eb.png)

Somehow it seems that for the total cpu usage, glances is writing too many column values (11 columns for the header row and nearly all data rows / 12 columns for some data rows). Up to processcount_total all the data looks fine in the second line.

Please let me know if you should require more information to debug this issue. Thanks a lot in advance!
#### Versions
- Glances (glances -V): Glances v2.6.1
- PSutil (glances -V): psutil v4.1.0
- Operating System (lsb_release -a): Windows 2008ServerR2 SP1 64bit

body:

- running glances in tmux
- after some hours of run the following error will occur:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):/python2.7/site-packages/bernhard/__init__.py", line 54, in read_exactly
  File "/home/argus/venv/bin/glances", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('Glances==2.6', 'console_scripts', 'glances')()
  File "/home/argus/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/__init__.py", line 133, in main
    standalone.serve_forever()
  File "/home/argus/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/standalone.py", line 107, in serve_forever
    return self.__serve_forever()
  File "/home/argus/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/standalone.py", line 92, in __serve_forever
    self.screen.update(self.stats)
  File "/home/argus/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/outputs/glances_curses.py", line 975, in update
    self.flush(stats, cs_status=cs_status)
  File "/home/argus/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/outputs/glances_curses.py", line 953, in flush
    self.display(stats, cs_status=cs_status)
  File "/home/argus/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/outputs/glances_curses.py", line 524, in display
    args=self.args, max_width=plugin_max_width)
  File "/home/argus/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/plugins/glances_plugin.py", line 555, in get_stats_display
    'msgdict': self.msg_curse(args),
  File "/home/argus/venv/lib/python2.7/site-packages/Glances-2.6-py2.7.egg/glances/plugins/glances_fs.py", line 229, in msg_curse
    for i in sorted(self.stats, key=comparsion_key):
TypeError: string indices must be integers, not str

I'm working on finding the root-cause for the issue. I'll post it here if I find.

Use  `isinstance(x, dict)` for all the items to check if it is a proper `comparsion_key` **or** avoid adding a non-dict instance to the list.

title: IndexError in browser mode
body:
**New pull request to address fix in develop**

I was trying to run glances in browser mode and got below `IndexError`. This happens only when there is no server available. On probing further I found that the problem was comparison of active_server with `NoneType` with `is`. In failure case `active_server` is 0, hence the condition failed. I grep'd through the code and found that `active_server` holds the current cursor position and its an integer. Hope this fix helps. BTW, awesome project. I am still learning new stuff from glances!

```
(env)rkadam@rkadam-vbox:~/github/glances$ glances --browser
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/rkadam/github/glances/env/bin/glances", line 9, in <module>

title: Refresh time not take into account in Web Server mode
body:
I was using glances -t 15 in order to force it to update only once every 15 seconds. This worked great, and kept the CPU usage of Glances down! Now I'm trying to use it in web server mode, but -t doesn't seem to do anything. No matter what I do, it always updates once every 3 seconds and is using 13% CPU to do it!

Source:  https://groups.google.com/forum/?utm_medium=email&utm_source=footer#!msg/glances-users/CpiI6ISyCsI/PB3WJWs0BwAJ

@nclsHart / @notFloran : can you have a look, refresh time (-t option) does not work as expected in (-w) mode.

title: '--tree' breaks process filter on Debian 8
body:
I saw similar issue with OSX/FreeBSD/Windows #542 where it was claimed that this was an bug exclusive to those operating systems. However I have a similar bug on a dedicated machine running **Debian 8.2**.

Running `glances --tree` and trying to filter the processes leads to glances being stuck at 100% CPU on one core.

Sometimes the prompt (with the filter) stays open, sometimes it manages to disappear before glances freezes.

I am connecting from a windows machine, using cygwin+tmux and tmux inside the root. But I don't think this is the reason for the freeze. Some information about the root:

python --version

title: Relatively high CPU usage
body:
This might be a low priority issue but is there any way that  the CPU usage of glances can be cut down? It's not usually an issue for me since, at most, it seems to take between 10% and 20% CPU across differing hardware but fluctuates every few seconds and usually drops a bit lower. The only times where I see this to be more of a problem is when I'm monitoring servers that are under very high loads.

For example, lets say I'm looking at a server with 40 cores, 128 GB RAM, and 4 SSDs in a RAID setup. This server is hit incredibly hard because it's sole purpose is to host a RDBMS. It would be nice to not have glances suck up as much CPU as it does now so there's more available to the RDBMS that really needs it.

I should note that I'm always running glances with the system default python which is 2.x (I'm either using it on RHEL, CentOS 6/7, or some version of Ubuntu Server). Is there a noticeable improvement when using this with Python 3.x instead of 2.x?

title: Avoid crashing if LC_ALL is not defined by user
body:
When using SSH, my LC_ALL environment variable is not set (sshd configuration).
This seems to be a default configuration on Raspbian (equiv Debian 7.8) and Ubuntu 14.04.2.

The problem is that when launching glances via SSH in this manner, the program crash with a locale.Error exception line 98 in `__init.py__`. I'm no python specialist but as far as I understood the python 2.7 documentation, the statement `locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, '')` try to reset the locale for the python program to the user settings, which in my case are not defined. And I suspect that's the root of the problem.

So I propose a patch (commit `aadb49f`) where I do a try/except and simply pass the error, as anyway from the documentation the statement `locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, '')` should always work.

_Note: after that change, I can successfully run glances via SSH on my Raspberry Pi running Raspbian. See screenshot:_
![glances on raspberry pi](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1397088/6382142/906e9da6-bd46-11e4-9691-31545796c3c9.png)

title: Password support for multiple servers

Is there any way to have it either prompt for a password, or be able to specify a password in the glances.conf file (ie, server__x__password or something, where _x_ is, of course, the server ID)? title: Primary IP address detection error on Mac OS X (auto discover mode)
body:
The autodetection feature did not work as expected on Mac OS (and perhaps on others OS / Linux distro). 

Glances did not return the primary IP address in the glances_autodiscover.py script:

```
            zeroconf_bind_address = netifaces.ifaddresses(
                netifaces.interfaces()[1])[netifaces.AF_INET][0]['addr']
```

The interfaces list is the followning netifaces.interfaces():

```
[ lo0, stf0, en0, en1... ]
```

I use the en1 (Wifi), other interfaces have no IP addresses (except lo0).

Solution: parse all available interface (except lo0):
- if no IP address is detected, return lo0 (127.0.0.1) 
- if only one IP address is returned, return it
- if more than one interface is detected, ask to the user...

title: Quitting glances leaves a column layout to the current terminal
body:
I have a strange behaviour, which occurs only on specific tabs/windows on terminal.app (the default terminal on osX).
The curious thing is : on a fresh new tab, it works, on "old" tabs, it glitches.

![capture decran 2014-07-02 a 12 16 35](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8046211/3454572/3c213710-01d3-11e4-8265-d4ec698d1d8a.png)

Je switche en français pour des raisons de facilité : j'ai essayé plein de modifications de la configuration du terminal (il était configuré en ansi, je l'ai mis en mode xterm-256), rien ne bouge. Je suis sous osX 10.9, sous zsh, et j'ai installé glances via pip (en fait un upgrade de la 1.7). Que je quitte via "q" ou via un ctrl+c ne change rien, j'ai le message d'erreur et la console est inutilisable après cela à cause du layout en colonne (voir screenshot).
Et le truc "arrachage de cheveux", c'est que si je créé une nouvelle fenêtre ou un nouvel onglet, ça fonctionne correctement ... des fois. Je n'arrive pas à isoler suffisamment le soucis pour faire un bug report plus précis.

Glances pré-2.0 avait le même soucis lorsque je l'avais testé (et abandonné dû à ce soucis).

Message d'erreur que j'ai essayé de recoller en lignes :
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/usr/local/bin/glances", line 9, in <module>

title: glances crashes with malformed UTF-8 sequences in process command lines
body:
Glances was running normally but then it crashed with an UnicodeDecodeError. I've tried to re-run it but it keeps returning the same error, which follows.

The process ID 2194, given in the first part of the traceback, refers to a process whose command line contains a malformed UTF-8 sequence (probably due to a KDE bug). This seems to be the key of the error, because closing that program allowed Glances to run normally again. Regularly formed UTF-8 sequences seem to work without problems. Please let me know if I can give any further information to help diagnose the problem.

title: display users without username correctly
Bug when parsing configuration file.
body:
Bonjour,

Glances ne se termine pas de façon "propre" lorsqu'une regex est mal écrite dans le fichier de configuration.

On est obligé de lancer la commande "reset", pour retrouver un terminal normal.

Voici la configuration qui permet de reproduire le problème :

``` conf
[monitor]
list_1_description=OpenSSH
list_1_regex=*sshd* 
```

Et la commande : 

``` shell
$ glances -C ~/.glances.conf
```

À noter que si on rajoute la ligne

``` conf
list_1_countmin=1
```

La terminaison se fait de manière plus propre (bon, après les messages d'erreurs sont assez obscures pour quelqu'un qui n'a jamais touché à Python).

Bug très minime, et je pense qu'il doit y avoir d'autres cas similaires lorsque l'on écrit des mauvaises règles de configuration.

Cordialement,
-TOSH-

title: Argument parser: try-except blocks never get triggered
body:
For instance:

```
$ glances -P
option -P requires argument
[...]
```

the `GetoptError` exception is raised and the generic statement is being printed. So, try-except blocks never get executed.
Regarding the `-p/--port` flag, the check if port number passed as argument is integer doesn't work at all:

```
$ glances -s -p AAAA
[...]
```

Also, the locale variable `port_number` is assigned but never used.

title: Defining password in client/server mode doesn't work as intended
body:
If you bypass issue #314, the new interactive method to enter a password in client/server mode doesn't work as intended.

```
$ glances -s --password
Glances server is running on 0.0.0.0:61209
```

The reason of this is:

``` python
       [...]
        elif opt in ("-P", "--password"):
            try:
                arg
            except NameError:
                print(_("Error: -P flag need an argument (password)"))
                sys.exit(2)
            password = arg
       [...]
```

The two flags are being processed the same way, while actually both relate to different methods.

body:

```

Is this a bug or a feature? :-)

title: FreeBSD 9.2 & Python 3.3 = Glances pas content...
body:
Bonjour nico,

Tout d'abord merci pour cet utilitaire que tu as fait.

Je l'utilise depuis peu mais je le trouve vraiment super bien foutu, il remplace le "top" de main de maitre :)

Cependant, j'ai récement voulu changer un peu l'update des packets sur mes FreeBSD et je suis confronté à un problème.

Sous FreeBSD 9.x avec la version de Python par défaut (donc de FBSD) qui est en 2.7, glances se porte comme un charme.

Par contre quand je passe en version 3.3 de Python, toujours avec FBSD, j'obtiens un message de ce style :

```
root@von-neumann:~ # glances
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/bin/glances", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('Glances==1.7.1', 'console_scripts', 'glances')()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Glances-1.7.1-py3.3.egg/glances/glances.py", line 4353, in main
    config = Config()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Glances-1.7.1-py3.3.egg/glances/glances.py", line 228, in __init__
    self.load()
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.3/site-packages/Glances-1.7.1-py3.3.egg/glances/glances.py", line 236, in load
    self.parser.read(path)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.3/configparser.py", line 689, in read
    self._read(fp, filename)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.3/configparser.py", line 1010, in _read
    for lineno, line in enumerate(fp, start=1):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.3/encodings/ascii.py", line 26, in decode
    return codecs.ascii_decode(input, self.errors)[0]
UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode byte 0xc2 in position 1322: ordinal not in range(128)
```

D'après ce que j'ai pu lire, Glances peut tourner avec la version 3.3 de Python mais à prioris pas sous FBSD...

Je ne sais pas si d'autres personnes ont eu ce genre de soucis mais je préfére le signaler quand même :)

Merci pour le taff que tu fais avec Glances et bonne continuation !

al.

title: Crash during laptop sleep/wakeup due to battery module
body:
Hi,

I run glances in my laptop (Dell latitude d630, intel core2duo, Debian testing, 3.10-ish kernel), and I usually leave glances running when I close the lid and put it to sleep.

Sometimes (but not always), glances crashes at some point during the sleep/wakeup cycle. The usual console messages look like this:

```
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file current_now
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file charge_now
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file charge_full
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file capacity
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file status
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file voltage_now
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file uevent
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file model_name
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file manufacturer
CRITICAL:batinfo.battery:Can not read file technology
Traceback (most recent call last):
File "/usr/local/bin/glances", line 9, in <module> load_entry_point('Glances==1.7.1', 'console_scripts', 'glances')()
File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 4471, in main stats.update()
File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 1492, in update self.__update__(input_stats)
File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 1437, in __update__ self.batpercent = self.glancesgrabbat.getcapacitypercent()
File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 1115, in getcapacitypercent bsum = bsum + int(self.bat_list[bcpt].capacity) ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: ''
```

It seems that my kernel/udev/whatever isn't making available the files under `/sys/class/power_supply` for a few seconds during the sleep/wakeup cycle, which makes the battery library return empty strings instead of numeric values. I suggest Glances handles this condition gracefully.

title: Additional output "HTML" can't find default.html
body:
Ubuntu 12.04, pip install glances, glances 1.6.1, jinja2 2.7, psutil 0.7.1

After having a closer look at get_work_path, I find that it looks in these directories:

local_path: /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/glances/data
share_path: /usr/share/glances
sys.prefix: /usr

Meanwhile, the template only exists on this location on my system:
/usr/local/share/glances/html/default.html

...so until further notice I've "fixed" the problem by replacing "return work_path" with this:
return '/usr/local/share/glances/'

title: Crash under Debian on ARM
body:
Hi,

I'm using glances v1.6-1 with python-psutil v0.5.1-1 in a Debian box with ARM architecture (armv5tel 2.6.33.6-preempt kernel).

After running perfectly for a few minutes, glances crashes with this stack trace (line breaks manually added for your viewing pleasure):

```
23.05.2013 11:52:54 Traceback (most recent call last):

File "/usr/share/glances/glances/glances.py", line 3696, in <module> main()

File "/usr/share/glances/glances/glances.py", line 3682, in main screen.update(stats)

File "/usr/share/glances/glances/glances.py", line 1760, in update self.flush(stats, cs_status=cs_status)

File "/usr/share/glances/glances/glances.py", line 1748, in flush self.display(stats, cs_status=cs_status)

File "/usr/share/glances/glances/glances.py", line 1712, in display processlist = stats.getProcessList(screen.getProcessSortedBy())

File "/usr/share/glances/glances/glances.py", line 1161, in getProcessList process[sortedby][3], reverse=sortedReverse)

File "/usr/share/glances/glances/glances.py", line 1160, in <lambda> process[sortedby][2] + process[sortedby][1] - KeyError: 'io_counters'
```

This error is reminiscent of an issue I have with iotop, as my ARM box (and its kernel) lack some accounting features:

```
# iotop
Could not run iotop as some of the requirements are not met:
- Linux >= 2.6.20 with
  - I/O accounting support (CONFIG_TASKSTATS, CONFIG_TASK_DELAY_ACCT, CONFIG_TASK_IO_ACCOUNTING)
```

Wild guess on my part (I might be wrong): glances does not check these counters exist before using them.

title: Problème de lancement de Glances sur un serveur Debian (OpenVZ server hôte)...
body: Salut Nicolas, J'apprécie beaucoup ton blog que je suis régulièrement. Merci pour cet outil Glances très pratique qui complète bien mon outil de supervision (Nagios-Centreon). Tu as fais du bon boulot ! J'utilise surtout Glances lorsque J'ai un problème de perf sur une machine et que je veux l'avoir à l'oeil. Glances me remonte de nombreux paramètres dont j'ai besoin ce qui me facilite le diagnostique. Je te remercie beaucoup pour ça ! J'ai testé la version 1.6 de Glances en l'installant via pip. J'ai fais le premier test sur un serveur Debian OpenVZ (kernel: 2.6.32-5-openvz-amd64) sur lequel je n'ai eu aucun problème. Seulement, le deuxième essai sur un autre serveur Debian OpenVZ (kernel: 2.6.32-bpo.5-openvz-amd64) m'a donné une erreur et l'interface de Glances n'apparait pas ! Voici l'erreur: Traceback (most recent call last): File "/usr/local/bin/glances", line 9, in load_entry_point('Glances==1.6', 'console_scripts', 'glances')() File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 3679, in main stats.update() File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 1067, in update self.**update**(input_stats) File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 1049, in **update** self.glancesgrabprocesses.update() File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 723, in update procstat = self.**get_process_stats**(proc) File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/glances/glances.py", line 670, in **get_process_stats** procstat['username'] = proc.username File "/usr/local/lib/python2.6/dist-packages/psutil/**init**.py", line 306, in username return pwd.getpwuid(self.uids.real).pw_name KeyError: 'getpwuid(): uid not found: 1500' As tu déjà rencontré ce problème ? Autres questions: - Est ce que l'on peux régler le niveau de déclenchement des alertes, par exemple pour le status "Warning" du load average ? - Est ce qu'il est possible d'avoir le log sous les yeux et le sauvegarder en même temps dans un fichier texte ? Merci pour ton aide.

title: glances reports incorrect error message
body:
### bug

Trying to run glances in my linode VPS and it kept complaining about psutil not being installed. 

I pip installed and apt-get installed psutil, and found psutil throwing a RuntimeException, which glances was incorrectly reporting that psutil wasn't installed correctly.

https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/master/glances/glances.py#L140

```
In [1]: import psutil

In [2]: psutil.disk_io_counters()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
RuntimeError                              Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-2da8412c0a57> in <module>()
----> 1 psutil.disk_io_counters()

/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/psutil/__init__.pyc in disk_io_counters(perdisk)
   1039     rawdict = _psplatform.disk_io_counters()
   1040     if not rawdict:
-> 1041         raise RuntimeError("couldn't find any physical disk")
   1042     if perdisk:
   1043         for disk, fields in rawdict.items():

RuntimeError: couldn't find any physical disk
```

I'm not sure why it can't find my physical disk, but the error message quite ambiguous and not helpful, since psutil is installed

Mount shows I do have a disk, so I don't know what isn't correctly configured...

$ mount
/dev/xvda on / type ext3 (rw,noatime,errors=remount-ro)
tmpfs on /lib/init/rw type tmpfs (rw,nosuid,mode=0755)

tmpfs on /dev/shm type tmpfs (rw,nosuid,nodev)
devpts on /dev/pts type devpts (rw,noexec,nosuid,gid=5,mode=620)
/var/run on /run type /var/run (rw,bind)
/var/lock on /run/lock type /var/lock (rw,bind)
/dev/shm on /run/shm type /dev/shm (rw,bind)
### versions

Glances 1.5.1
Python 2.7.3rc2 
Linode VPS, Debian 5.0ish

title: OSX 10.8.0: 'vmem' object has no attribute 'cached'
body:
```
$ glances
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/bin/glances", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('Glances==1.4.2', 'console_scripts', 'glances')()
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/glances.py", line 2239, in main
    stats.update()
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/glances.py", line 753, in update
    self.__update__()
  File "/opt/local/Library/Frameworks/Python.framework/Versions/2.7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/glances/glances.py", line 604, in __update__
    self.mem = {'cache': phymem.cached + phymem.buffers,
AttributeError: 'vmem' object has no attribute 'cached'
```

[glances is making a `psutil.virtual_memory()`](https://github.com/nicolargo/glances/blob/master/glances/glances.py#L605) which indeed [has no `.cached` on osx](http://code.google.com/p/psutil/source/browse/trunk/psutil/_psosx.py?r=1540#35).

title: glances.py has #! /usr/bin/python hard-coded
body: Most BSD systems do not have python installed in /usr/bin (generally in /usr/ports or /usr/pkgsrc).  Do not hardcode the path, find it during configure (which it does anyway) and "patch" the .py.  Or use « #! /usr/bin/env python » but even that is error prone.
